content:
OK, that took way longer than it should have, but we now have this being auto-published:

https://rust-lang.github.io/wg-traits/welcome.html

and in particular there is a rendered form of the skill tree based on this toml source
I had hoped to use this @Jack Huey to lay out more steps but that'll have to come next week
I want to maybe add a few more features too, like some "status emoji" indicators or something...
note though that there are some links
e.g. you can click on "Make intern methods take &self"
to get taken over to the issue that @Jane Lusby has been working on

nikomatsakis said:

I had hoped to use this Jack Huey to lay out more steps but that'll have to come next week

in particular I wanted to use this to move over some of the stuff from #wg-traits > issue triage and labels

May i suggest adding "inherent associated type" to this skill tree as an explicit goal too... It's currently the oldest tracking issue kept open at https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/8995. Github comments said it's also blocked on lazy normalization.
I read the latest "Inside Rust" blog post, and I'd like to know what features about the skill tree you are missing or would like to have?

I mentioned it but I don't think anybody filed an issue: we probably need a legend on the skill tree, emojis are not (all) self-explanatory. Another thing that would be nice to have is a control scheme that usually goes with that kind of infographics (zoom, dragging, etc.)

@Ludwig Stecher I was hoping to start drawing up a feature list, but yes a legend would be an immediate place to start. In general, I think if somebody wanted to start iterating on the visual appearance, that'd be very welcome. I'd like to move it closer to what you see in that wasm post (that might mean moving away from graphviz and doing a bit more of the layout manually, and that'd be ok by me too)
in general I think we should be focusing on highlighting the places people can contribute more
doing a better job of greying out things that are inapplicable, perhaps, etc
